Not sure where I read this, but my understanding is that these tsuba were m=
ade from the "spoked" tsuba that we often see. I guess that could be proven=
 if a "mukade" tsuba were unwrapped...but of course, that would be a major =
sin! 

Ron
STL

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Tom Helm 
  To: nih=
ontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, November 04, 2007 12:41 PM
  Sub=
ject: Re: [nihontostudy] How to call this odd one?


  Yecheal -
  Not sure=
 how to address you, this is called a Shingen or Mukade 
  tsuba. Not so od=
d to those who have been around the study for awhile. 
  These are so calle=
d as it is said, but has not been proven, that 
  Takeda Shingen's hand-pic=
ked personal guard and messenger unit the 
  Mukade-Tai wore these on their=
 swords. Shingen himself is said to 
  have awarded these as badges of meri=
t to his troops. For this reason 
  they are quite popular and there have b=
een many copies of this design.
  Your example looks to be all copper given=
 that the surface of the 
  seppa-dai appears to have been hammered and the=
re are tiny stars 
  punched into the surface. Originals if such a thing ex=
ists are indeed 
  copper or brass wire woven thru an iron plate. Mukade BT=
W means 
  Centipede...
  -t
